measured_by: choice between Random and Distinctive lottery ticket sequences
justification: Part 1 asked subjects to "make a series of choices between lottery tickets" where Random sequences were paired with Distinctive sequences; these choices were used to test preferences predicted by the representativeness heuristic.

measured_by: choice between Random and Previous‐draw lottery ticket sequences
justification: The design included tickets "Previous" that contained numbers drawn in the prior lottery and compared them with Random tickets to see whether participants avoided recent winners—an RH-based measure.

measured_by: choice between Random and Distant-Previous lottery ticket sequences
justification: A third ticket type ("Distant Previous") used numbers from an older draw; comparing preferences for Random versus Distant-Previous sequences served as another operationalization of RH susceptibility.
"In Part 2, we gave our subjects a number of puzzles previously used to measure susceptibility to the RH, such as the well-known Linda problem."
The Taxi problem is listed among the RH puzzles and normative versus heuristic answers were analyzed to index representativeness-based reasoning.
The Hospitals item appears in the set of six RH puzzles whose correct versus heuristic responses were recorded.
The Families question (estimating frequency of a specific birth order) is included among the puzzles "used to measure susceptibility to the RH."
The article labels a "high school puzzle" as one of the six RH tasks whose answers were scored for representativeness-consistent errors.
A "Marbles" item is listed in Table 5 and is treated as another puzzle diagnosing RH-consistent responding.

measured_by: Faith in Intuition subscale of the Rational-Experiential Inventory
justification: The review notes that "people scoring high on the Faith in Intuition subscale of their Rational-Experiential Inventory (REI)… tended to display a ‘heuristic’ mode of responding," indicating this subscale operationalizes the experiential style construct.

measured_by: Need for Cognition subscale of the Rational-Experiential Inventory
justification: Epstein et al. (1996) also found that "people scoring low on the Need for Cognition subscale" differed in heuristic use, implying that the NFC subscale measures the rational/analytic style dimension.
Both field experiments "added a question from the Cognitive Reflection Test (CRT) (Frederick, 2005)" expressly to capture individual differences in cognitive reflection relevant to heuristic use.
